data.title: The Best Movies With Bridge in the Title
data.meta_description: Over 90 filmgoers have voted on the 100+ films on Best Movies With Bridge in the Title. Current Top 3: A Bridge Too Far, The Bridge on the River Kwai, Lulu on ...
data.text:
How many movies with bridge in the title can you name? This list ranks the best movies with bridge in the name, whether they're documentaries, dramas, horror movies, or any other genre of film. Do you have a favorite movie with bridge in the title? Categorizing movies by words in their titles is kind of uncommon, but that's a big part of why this list is so fun to scroll through. There's probably one movie with bridge in the title you think of right away, but you might be shocked to see how many others exist as well.

Notable films with bridge in the title include The Bridge on the River Kwai, A Bridge Too Far, and Bridge to Terabithia, although there are many more examples on this list. This poll is interactive, meaning you can vote the bridge movies up or down depending on how much you like them.

Most divisive: Howrah Bridge

Over 90 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The Best Movies With Bridge in the Title

A Bridge Too Far, a gripping war epic, demonstrates the power of a bridge both as a strategic point and as a connecting force between people in times of conflict. The film portrays the disastrous Operation Market Garden during World War II, where the word "bridge" becomes symbolic for the soldiers' fruitless efforts to reach their objective - a bridge too distant, suggesting that even ambition has its limits. As the story unfolds, bridges serve as battlegrounds where characters display courage, camaraderie, and strategy, thus asserting themselves not only as physical structures but also as emotional touchstones. The film's title and theme provide a timeless and uncompromising look at war, human resilience, and the consequences of pushing boundaries.

Released : 1977

Directed by : Richard Attenborough

Also ranks # 15 on The Best War Movies Of All Time

Also ranks # 19 on The Best Movies Based on Non-Fiction Books

Also ranks # 210 on The 300+ Best Epic Movies Of All Time

The Bridge on the River Kwai is not merely a gripping war film but a powerful exploration of the complexities of human nature under duress. The titular bridge becomes a symbol of both cooperation and conflict, as British POWs led by Colonel Nicholson (played masterfully by Alec Guinness) are forced to construct the eponymous bridge for their Japanese captors. Tensions rise as the bridge comes to reflect the moral quandary faced by Nicholson, torn between his duty as a soldier and his innate sense of decency. In the end, the bridge illustrates the gulf between honor and humanity, making The Bridge on the River Kwai an enduring classic that resonates with audiences to this day.

Released : 1957

Directed by : David Lean

Dig Deeper Movies That Won Best Picture at the Oscars and Golden Globes

Also ranks # 19 on The Best War Movies Of All Time

Also ranks # 12 on The Very Best Oscar-Winning Movies For Best Picture

Lulu on the Bridge tells a captivating tale of intrigue, love, and self-discovery set against the backdrop of an alluring and mysterious bridge. In this film, the titular bridge not only alludes to the physical location where the protagonist, played by Harvey Keitel, finds a peculiar stone but also signifies the bridge between reality and illusion. As the protagonist delves into the enigmatic stone's powers, he embarks on a metaphorical bridge to understanding love, life, and the forces that govern existence. Profoundly compelling and deeply introspective, Lulu on the Bridge invites audiences to cross their own bridges and explore the depths of the human heart, mind, and soul.

Released : 1998

Directed by : Paul Auster

Tom Hanks, Mark Rylance, Alan Alda

Bridge of Spies exemplifies the mastery of director Steven Spielberg, in a Cold War thriller that uses the experience of crossing a bridge as a metaphor for navigating the treacherous waters of international politics and espionage. With the pivotal exchange of captured spies on the Glienicke Bridge, the film reveals how bridges can serve as conduits for transferring not only people but also secrets and allegiances. In this tense and atmospheric film, the literal bridge is a place of vulnerability and exposure where one's true loyalties are laid bare. In its gripping portrayal of the Cold War era, Bridge of Spies deftly highlights the role of bridges in shaping human destinies and reflects on the fragile nature of trust.

Released : 2015

Directed by : Steven Spielberg

Also ranks # 18 on Every Steven Spielberg Movie, Ranked By Fans

Also ranks # 100 on The Best Political Films Of All Time

Also ranks # 45 on The Best CIA Movies Of All Time

The Lovers on the Bridge, directed by the visionary Leos Carax, tells a poignant love story set against the backdrop of the crumbling Pont-Neuf Bridge in Paris. This film uses the bridge as an evocative symbol for the unlikely connection between two lost and damaged souls, played masterfully by Juliette Binoche and Denis Lavant. As their passionate, tumultuous relationship unfolds, the bridge becomes a refuge and a witness to their love, while simultaneously serving as a metaphor for the emotional bridge they must build to overcome their past traumas. With its breathtaking visuals and raw emotionality, The Lovers on the Bridge not only pays homage to the power of love but also underscores the significance of bridges in connecting people across boundaries.

Released : 1991

Directed by : Leos Carax

Vivien Leigh, Robert Taylor, Lucile Watson

Waterloo Bridge, a heart-wrenching wartime romance, showcases how symbolic bridges can become in the lives of characters as they traverse through love and loss. Set during World War II, the film's eponymous bridge serves as both witness to and backdrop for the ill-fated love story between a soldier and a ballerina. As their relationship deepens, the Waterloo Bridge becomes emblematic of the crossing from innocence to heartbreak, reflecting the harsh realities that befall lovers separated by war. This enduring classic reinforces the idea that bridges can symbolize not only physical connection but also emotional passage through life's most profound moments.

Released : 1940

Directed by : Mervyn LeRoy

Also ranks # 57 on The Best Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Movies List

Also ranks # 11 on The Best Romance Movies Of The 1940s
